Erik Hetzner wrote:
> At Fri, 08 Aug 2008 20:23:32 +0200,
> Jean-Noï¿½l Rivasseau <elvanor@...> wrote:
>> It seems to me Heritrix does not consider the hash nor save it in the 
>> arc files. It could be useful to add this support.
>>
>> What do you think?
> 
> The URI fragment (aka hash) is interpreted by the client and is media
> type specific. The client-server interaction to retrieve the two
> URIs:
> 
> a) http://example.org/test#a
> b) http://example.org/test#b
> 
> is going to be identical. The only difference is in client-side
> display/interpretation of the result. 

Good explanation of the network-equivalence of two URIs differing only 
after the '#'. But regarding...

> I cannot imagine why it would be
> useful to store this data, but I can imagine why it would cause
> problems. Can you describe some ways in which it might be helpful?

The situation I've seen is where a JS/AJAXy application uses the 
'#fragment' to affect the rendering or behavior of the page. For 
example, I've seen it used analogously to a client-side query-string:

http://example.com/app#redirectTo=/help

Javascript in such a page might load different URIs, construct different 
outlinks, or do an immediate redirect to a different URI depending on 
the '#fragment'. Theoretically (but not yet), Heritrix could find those 
links if it preserved the '#fragment'. (It also might need to 
re-extract, though not necessarily re-fetch, that same URI when it is 
encountered with a different '#fragment' later.)

- Gordon @ IA
